resources.string: Choose the body you\'d like to check out

Largest, and most massive object within our solar system, containing 99.8% of overall mass, \nOfficially classified as a yellow dwarf, the Sun is a comparatively small star \nThe oldest body in our solar system at 4.6 billion years old

The Sun has a radius of 695,508 kilometers(432,168.6 miles). 
While our star isn't among the biggest around it's still very massive, 332,946 times more so than Earth. 
It's 150 million kilometers(93 million miles) away from earth, this distance serves as a basis for an Astronomical Unit(AU). 
The nearest interstellar neighbor of our solar system is Alpha Centauri, 4.37 light years away.

As a non-solid body different parts of The Sun rotate at different rates, at the equator one rotation takes 25 Earth days, at the poles that same action takes 36 days. \nOur solar system is moving at 720,000 kilometers per hour(450,000 miles) per hour. Even at that speed it takes around 230 million years to make a full rotation around the Milky Way.
